prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
These observations are necessary because only ALMA can reach the necessary dynamic range that would enable us to see CO(0-1) absorption on this bright mm continuum.
The requested 1 sigma sensitivity of 0.6mJy on a 510mJy continuum ensures that the absorption will be seen at 5 sigma, as long as the clouds cover more than 0.5% of the area of their background continuum source.
This sensitivity will also enable us to reach the ~1x10^8 m_sun limit for the outflow in emission, which is known from our previous PdB CO(1-0) observations. This mass limit is computed under the assumptions that the ALMA data can be binned 5 times (to ∼25 km/s), that the outflow is spread over a 700 km/s velocity range, that a=0.8 M_sun/(K km/s pc^2), and that the beam size is 0.5”. This value is 1 order of magnitude better than the resolution of our PdB data. It will help us separate the two nuclei by ∼2 beams, and to limit the outﬂow extent to 1 kpc.
Several continuum images at lower spectral resolution are asked, for us to construct the deepest possible continuum cube.

The sensitivity was calculated assuming that the SLED of the gas in the outflow is identical to that in the ambient medium, i.e., using a I_CO(3-2)/I_CO(1-0) value of 2.6 for the outflow, as we previously found it to be for the ambient gas. This part of the SLED is very similar for the ambient gas in 4C12.50 and for the Milky Way. In the more likely scenario in which shock-related collisions are important in the ouflow, making its SLED resemble that of NGC6240, then the CO(3-2)-based outflow mass limit will be 3x10^7 M_sun, i.e., 3.5 times deeper than that from the CO(1-0) observations.
The mm continuum is high enough at this frequency that it again permits the detection of the outflow in CO(2-3) absorption.
As before, we ask for continuum cubes to be obtained at a lower spectral resolution, which will help us construct the deepest possible continuum cube.
The spectral and spatial resolution of these observations are identical to those at restframe 115GHz to enable direct comparisons of the outflow properties.

The sensitivity was again calculated assuming that the SLED of the gas in the outflow is identical to that in the ambient medium, i.e., using the same S_CO(4-3)/S_CO(1-0) for the ambient medium and for the outflow, 2.8. We have no previous SLED data for the CO(4-3) line in 4C12.50. we instead assume that it follows well the SLED of the Milky Way, as it can be seen for the transitions up to (3-2). These observations will enable us to detect an outflow with a mass of 1x10^7 M_sun in case the CO in the outflow is excited in a way similat to that in NGC6240. Only ALMA can perfom these observations. The assumed spectral and spatial resolution of our observations are the same as for CO(1-0).

The sensitivity computation for this line differs than that for other lines in the sense that it is based on the detection of the ambient gas emission instead of that of the outflow, because the SLED shape is presently unknown at CO J=(6-5) and it may vary signiﬁcantly depending on the gas T and density. We ask for a sensitivity that will enable a secure, 5 sigma detection of the ambient medium emission, assuming that its brightness temperature is the same as that of CO(4-3). This is a most important line for the determination of the mass of the 400K gas in the ambient medium. Only ALMA can do these observations.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Black holes have been claimed able to heat the gas in galaxies via jet/radiation-driven shock fronts. Indeed, evidence of heating of the molecular gas in an AGN-driven outflow was recently discovered: using Spitzer, IRAM Plateau de Bure & 30m telescope, and Herschel data of a radio-loud and ultraluminous-infrared galaxy, 4C12.50, we demonstrated that the mass ratio of warm (~400K) to cold (~25K) gas is >=30 times higher in the outflow than in the ambient medium. Our conclusion that the accelerated gas is heated is robust against major sources of uncertainty including the CO-intensity-to-H2-mass conversion factor, the warm gas temperature from rotational H2 lines, and the warm gas mass probed by high-J CO lines. Motivated by this result, we request CO(1-0), (3-2), (4-3), and (6-5) observations to compare the spectral line energy distribution in the outflow and in the ambient medium of 4C12.50. Our goal is to test whether the gas heating is detectable as an excess emission by CO molecules in intermediate rotational states J, facilitating the discovery of outflows at intermediate/high z. We request 3.2 hrs for a project that can serve as a reference for future outflow searches.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: Hunting for the highest-momentum molecular gas outflows in BAL QSOs
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Radio cores shedding light on molecular outflows

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Center for Computational Sciences, University of Tsukuba
